Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The research fellowship awarded to Ian Shipman is in the field of Algebraic Geometry. The host institution for the fellowship is University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Robert Lazarsfeld.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algebraic geometry is the study of the geometry of the solution sets to systems
of polynomial equations in several variables.  One can ask many question about
such solution sets.  For example, if p(x,y,z) is a cubic polynomial, does the
set of points where p(x,y,z) = 0 contain any lines?  If so, how many?  This
classical problem has been solved for a long time.  However, the field of
algebraic geometry is very much alive and people are discovering beautiful new
results all the time.

The solution set to a system of polynomial equations is called an algebraic
variety.  The circle defined by x^2 + y^2 = 1 is a good example to keep in mind.
At each point on the circle, there is a tangent line.  There is a new object
which consists of pairs of a point p on the circle, and a point on the tangent
line at p.  This is an example of a structure called a vector bundle.  The study
of vector bundles on an algebraic variety can give deep insight into its
geometry.
 
One line of inquiry I pursued with M. Brown has to do with special vector     
bundles called tilting bundles.  It is not so important to know exactly what a
tilting bundle is, but rather that it may be connected with a fundamental
property of algebraic varieties called rationality.  Sometimes it is possible to
describe the vicinity of a point on an algebraic variety using a coordinate
system which is also algebraic.  For example, if you were to take the point
(1,0) on the circle and join it to any point on the x-axis by a line, the line
would meet the circle in exactly one other point.  If you were to solve for the
coordinates of this point in terms of the x-coordinate of the point on the
x-axis, you would get ratios of polynomials.  This means that the circle is
rational.  (However, y^2 = x(x+1)(x+2) is not rational!)  Dr. Brown and I
investigated whether or not the existence of a tilting bundle on an algebraic
variety implies the variety is rational and found that the answer is yes in some
cases.  Our work clarifies this exciting connection, but there is still much
work to be done.

Another line of inquiry, followed with R. Kulkarni and Y. Mustopa, also has to do
with vector bundles.  We studied a special class of vector bundles called Ulrich
bundles.  Again, it is not so crucial to understand what an Ulrich bundle is to
get the point of the project.  Any variety which has an Ulrich bundle also has a
handful of other exciting properties that tend to be difficult to understand on
their own.  Our contribution was to expand the tools available to researchers
studying Ulrich bundles and to stress-test some new techniques.  In particular,
we show that it is possible to reduce a problem about Ulrich bundles on a
high-dimensional variety to a problem about one-dimensional varieties.

Finally, in joint work with D. Halpern-Leistner we studied an exotic form of
symmetry of algebraic varieties that is related to string theory.  We were able
to understand the structure of those symmetries that arise from a construction
first detailed by string theorists.
